content.webTitle: Ashes 2013-14: All you need to know … and maybe a bit more

fields.headline: Ashes 2013-14: All you need to know … and maybe a bit more
fields.bodyText: THE LONG WAIT IS OVER Yes, 12 whole Sundays have passed since the end of the last Ashes series so it's clearly time for a rematch. It all begins late on Wednesday, starting at midnight. THE OPENING It is a Law of cricket that you have to watch the first ball of the Ashes, even if it means jolting yourself awake at 11.58pm. Seven years ago Steve Harmison bowled to slip at the Gabba; 12 years before that Michael Slater cut Phil DeFreitas for four. In July, shortly after the Red Arrows ripped across the Nottingham sky, James Pattinson bowled a loopy bouncer to Alastair Cook and it was called wide. Something will happen. the question Remind me why the Ashes are on so soon? In cricket's four-year cycle the Australian Ashes series came just before the World Cup, which did not help either side's preparation for the major limited-overs event. The Aussies are hosting the 2015 tournament, so this tour was brought forward to 2013-14, but the Olympics thwarted the possibility of England's home series moving to 2012 to even things out. Australia next visit England in 2015 and a new four-year cycle begins. THE HISTORY ■ All Tests: Aus 133 Eng 105 Drawn 93 ■ In Australia: Aus 86 Eng 57 Drawn 27 FIRST UP: THE GABBA The modern incarnation is one of those feature-free wraparound stadiums with high stands and multicoloured seats to give the impression of a full house at all times. Peter Siddle traditionally bowls well here in the Ashes on his birthday (a hat-trick in 2010) but that falls this year on the fifth day of the Test. ■ Tests: Aus 10 Eng 4 Drawn 5 ■ Last time: Eng 260 (Siddle 6-54) & 517-1 dec (Strauss 110, Cook 235*, Trott 135*); Aus 481 (Hussey 195, Haddin 136) & 107-1 ODDS TO WIN SERIES Aus 6-4 Eng Evs Drawn 9-2 (William Hill)
